concern:
Not sure if anyone else feels this way but it can be a lonely journey in grad school especially because of the niche stresses, things we have to deal with. 

Created a group me that will hopefully foster some community for people to talk with one another and build some friendships or the very least camaraderie 

Here’s the link to join: You're invited to my new group 'Grad School Community' on GroupMe. Click here to join: https://groupme.com/join_group/86601776/iTupsbUn

dialogue_total.statement: Hello! It's great to see you today. Feel free to share whatever's on your mind or any concerns you might have. I'm here to listen and support you.

Hey, thanks. Well, I've been feeling a bit isolated lately. It's like, with all the specific stresses and deadlines, it feels like nobody else really gets it even though we're all in the same boat, you know?

It sounds like you're experiencing a lot of pressure and feeling alone in it, even though others around you might be facing similar situations. What's been contributing to these feelings of isolation?

client: I guess it's mostly because of the workload and how everyone just seems so focused on their own stuff. It's hard to find time to actually connect with people beyond a quick chat in class or meetings.
It seems like the heavy workload and the fast-paced environment are making it tough for you to connect with others on a deeper level. How does that impact your overall mood or daily life?
client: It makes me feel kind of down and disconnected most of the time. I find myself just going through the motions without really enjoying anything or feeling like I'm part of a community.

You feel down and disconnected because the lack of meaningful connections leaves you feeling like you're just going through the motions. What do you think might help you feel more connected or engaged with others?

I think having a space where people can talk about their experiences and support each other might help. That's why I started the group on GroupMe, hoping it could be a place to build some friendships or at least share struggles.
It sounds like starting the GroupMe was a proactive step towards building those connections. How has the group been going so far?
It's still pretty new, so it's a bit slow right now, but a few people have shared their thoughts, which is nice. I'm hoping more people will join and start opening up.
It's great that some people are already sharing their thoughts. How do you feel when you see those interactions happening in the group?
client: It feels really good to see people engaging even a little. Like, it gives me hope that we can all support each other and that I'm not the only one feeling this way.
It sounds like those interactions are really important to you and bring a sense of hope and connection. How do you think growing this group might impact your feelings of disconnection?

client: I think if more people join and engage, it could really help lessen that sense of isolation I sometimes feel. It would be great to have a consistent support system where we can all check in and share what's going on.
Having a consistent support system sounds like it could be really meaningful. What do you think might encourage more people to join and participate in the group?

Maybe spreading the word more, like posting the link in different grad student forums or groups could help. Also, if people who join feel comfortable enough to share a bit about themselves, it might make others feel at ease to join in too.

Posting the link in forums and creating a welcoming environment sound like great steps. How would you like to start with spreading the word, and what might be some ways to encourage new members to share about themselves?

I think I’ll start by sharing it in a couple of Facebook groups and maybe even mention it to classmates. To encourage sharing, I could set the tone by introducing myself first and maybe have some icebreaker questions to get people talking.

That sounds like a solid plan! Starting with Facebook groups and classmates is a great step. How about setting a goal to post in two groups this week and choosing a couple of icebreaker questions to try out? What do you foresee as possible challenges, and how might you handle them?

Sure, setting a goal to post in two groups this week sounds doable. One challenge might be people just not engaging or seeing the post, so I guess I’d have to be patient and maybe try to keep the conversation going with whoever does join.

Being patient and keeping the conversation going are excellent strategies. How about setting up a plan to follow up with those who engage, and maybe consider an alternative way to reach out if the initial posts don't get much traction?

Yeah, following up is a good idea. I could message people individually who show interest or maybe ask for feedback on how to make the group more engaging. If the posts don't get much attention, I might try reaching out in person during classes or events to talk about it.

It sounds like you've got a solid plan in place to build your support system. Sharing in Facebook groups and with classmates, along with using icebreakers, are excellent steps. Setting a goal to post in two groups this week is a proactive approach. Remember, patience and persistence will be key if engagement is slow. Following up individually and asking for feedback are great ways to nurture connections. If needed, reaching out during classes or events can provide another avenue to spread the word. Keep up the great effort, and let's touch base next week to see how everything is progressing. You're doing a fantastic job taking initiative!
Thanks, I hope it all works out. I'll try to keep the momentum going and see what happens.
